prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum and CO observations of Eta Car

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
A NOTE ON EXPOSURE TIMES & SENSITIVITIES: Throughout the bands, we use a fiducial sensitivity of 1 K per 3 km/s channel. We expect a strongly significant detection in the cold gas of the Homunculus at this sensitivity and resolution, though there are no interferometric observations available to inform this expectation more precisely. While it may be possible to achieve some of our science goals with shorter exposures in each band, doing so would be a waste of telescope time as shorter observations would be overhead-dominated.
SENSITIVITY: Loinard et al (2012) detected CO 3-2 at a peak brightness temperature ~0.2 K in a 17.5" beam. CO 1-0 has not previously been detected, but it should have a similar brightness to CO 3-2 given the very high densities (n>10^6) in the cold H2 gas. Given the scale of the homunculus and the beam size, the maximum filling factor possible for their observations is 0.1, which implies that the brightness temperature of the Homunculus should be at least 2 K. Loinard observed an overall line width of ~200 km/s, but the narrowest component they detected was ~13 km/s, so with our sensitivity per 3 km/s channel of 1.0K, we are guaranteed to detect CO in the broad components.
However, we expect the actual size-scale of the emitting regions to be much more compact than the Homunculus, so the likely surface brighntess of individual knots will be much higher, >10K, and therefore easily detected.
The continuum sensitivity is 0.08 mJy, which yields a column sensitivity N~7x10^23 per square centimeter at 100 GHz assuming a standard dust-to-gas ratio, beta=1.75, and an opacity at 1mm of 0.011 g/cm^2. The total dust and free-free emission at this frequency is ~10 Jy, so there must be a substantial number of compact regions that exceed our flux sensitivity. If the flux is uniformly distributed across the Homunculus, the surface brightness is likely to be ~100 Jy/beam, though a more likely scenario is that the central Little Homunculus exceeds that flux density and the surrounding homunculus is much fainter. In any case, the continuum sensitivity should not be a limiting factor in our observations.

The spectral structure of Eta Carinae's ejecta is unexplored at high spatial resolution. The clumps may be hot and thermally or turbulently broadened to 10-100 km/s, or they may be cold and narrow. Probably, both cases will be observed. We require the highest spectral resolution for these bands in order to determine the structure in the lines. However, the wide bandwidth is even more important: Eta Car's eject span thousands of km/s in both red and blue, so we need the full bandwidth.

DATA RATES: Eta Car is an extremely interesting but as yet poorly-studied source in the millimeter. We have elected to observe all windows in spectral line rather than continuum mode because we expect many additional lines to be detected "serendipitously" in each window. The pioneering observations of Loinard et al (2012) have already revealed the fruitfulness of this approach, showing for example that H13CN 4-3 was detected in the same window as the CO 3-2 line. The lines they observed exhibited complex shapes even with the poor spatial resolution of APEX, so spectral averaging would risk losing essential information and also reducing or removing the archival value of these observations.

RESOLUTION: The maximum resolution available is needed at this band as spatial resolution is the limiting factor throughout the proposed observations; the Weigelt blobs and other resolved knots are smaller than 0.5". However, since these will still be the first observations of Eta Car in these lines and bands, we elect to use a "standard mode" setup rather than going directly for the longest cycle 3 baselines. We hope a characterization of the structure of the Homunculus with standard resolution can be used to demonstrate the feasibility of longer baselines in future cycles.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 N2H+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: N2H+ and Continuum observations of Eta Car

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
A NOTE ON EXPOSURE TIMES & SENSITIVITIES: Throughout the bands, we use a fiducial sensitivity of 1 K per 3 km/s channel. We expect a strongly significant detection in the cold gas of the Homunculus at this sensitivity and resolution, though there are no interferometric observations available to inform this expectation more precisely. While it may be possible to achieve some of our science goals with shorter exposures in each band, doing so would be a waste of telescope time as shorter observations would be overhead-dominated.
SENSITIVITY: The sensitivity calculation is essentially the same as that for CO, but we repeat the analysis using the numbers for N2H+. It is noteworthy that the N2H+ abundance is ~2 orders of magnitude higher in the Homnuculus than the general molecular ISM.
Loinard et al (2012) detected N2H+ 4-3 at a peak brightness temperature ~0.15 K in a 17.5" beam. Other transitions of N2H+ (1-0, 2-1, 3-2, etc.) have not previously been detected, and N2H+ 1-0 is expected to have a greater brightness than N2H+ 4-3 given the high densities (n>10^6) in the cold H2 gas. Given the scale of the homunculus and the beam size, the maximum filling factor possible for their observations is 0.1, which implies that the brightness temperature of the Homunculus should be at least 1.5 K. Loinard observed an overall line width of ~200 km/s, but the narrowest component they detected was ~13 km/s, so with our sensitivity per 3 km/s channel of 1.0K, we are guaranteed to detect N2H+ in the broad components.
However, we expect the actual size-scale of the emitting regions to be much more compact than the Homunculus, so the likely surface brighntess of individual knots will be much higher, >10K, and therefore easily detected.

[same as Band 3 CO] The spectral structure of Eta Carinae's ejecta is unexplored at high spatial resolution. The clumps may be hot and thermally or turbulently broadened to 10-100 km/s, or they may be cold and narrow. Probably, both cases will be observed. We require the highest spectral resolution for these bands in order to determine the structure in the lines. However, the wide bandwidth is even more important: Eta Car's eject span thousands of km/s in both red and blue, so we need the full bandwidth.

[same as Band 3 CO] DATA RATES: Eta Car is an extremely interesting but as yet poorly-studied source in the millimeter. We have elected to observe all windows in spectral line rather than continuum mode because we expect many additional lines to be detected "serendipitously" in each window. The pioneering observations of Loinard et al (2012) have already revealed the fruitfulness of this approach, showing for example that H13CN 4-3 was detected in the same window as the CO 3-2 line. The lines they observed exhibited complex shapes even with the poor spatial resolution of APEX, so spectral averaging would risk losing essential information and also reducing or removing the archival value of these observations.

[same as Band 3 CO] RESOLUTION: The maximum resolution available is needed at this band as spatial resolution is the limiting factor throughout the proposed observations; the Weigelt blobs and other resolved knots are smaller than 0.5". However, since these will still be the first observations of Eta Car in these lines and bands, we elect to use a "standard mode" setup rather than going directly for the longest cycle 3 baselines. We hope a characterization of the structure of the Homunculus with standard resolution can be used to demonstrate the feasibility of longer baselines in future cycles.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum and CO observations of Eta Car

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY: The sensitivity calculation is essentially the same as that for CO 1-0 in Band 3. We keep 3 km/s as the target line width to match the 3mm band.
The continuum sensitivity in a beam is about 1x10^23 cm^-2 following the same assumptions as Band 3.

[same as Band 3 CO] The spectral structure of Eta Carinae's ejecta is unexplored at high spatial resolution. The clumps may be hot and thermally or turbulently broadened to 10-100 km/s, or they may be cold and narrow. Probably, both cases will be observed. We require the highest spectral resolution for these bands in order to determine the structure in the lines. However, the wide bandwidth is even more important: Eta Car's eject span thousands of km/s in both red and blue, so we need the full bandwidth.

[same as Band 3 CO] DATA RATES: Eta Car is an extremely interesting but as yet poorly-studied source in the millimeter. We have elected to observe all windows in spectral line rather than continuum mode because we expect many additional lines to be detected "serendipitously" in each window. The pioneering observations of Loinard et al (2012) have already revealed the fruitfulness of this approach, showing for example that H13CN 4-3 was detected in the same window as the CO 3-2 line. The lines they observed exhibited complex shapes even with the poor spatial resolution of APEX, so spectral averaging would risk losing essential information and also reducing or removing the archival value of these observations.

RESOLUTION: At 0.2", the Little Homunuculus will start to be resolved, as will the individual Weigelt blobs. This high resolution will allow the first direct comparison to Hubble images on a comparable angular scale.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum and CO observations of Eta Car

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY: The sensitivity calculation is essentially the same as that for CO 1-0 in Band 3, though CO 3-2 was directly detected. We keep 3 km/s as the target line width to match the 3mm band.
The continuum sensitivity in a beam is about 4x10^22 cm^-2 following the same assumptions as Band 3.

[same as Band 3 CO] The spectral structure of Eta Carinae's ejecta is unexplored at high spatial resolution. The clumps may be hot and thermally or turbulently broadened to 10-100 km/s, or they may be cold and narrow. Probably, both cases will be observed. We require the highest spectral resolution for these bands in order to determine the structure in the lines. However, the wide bandwidth is even more important: Eta Car's eject span thousands of km/s in both red and blue, so we need the full bandwidth.

[same as Band 3 CO] DATA RATES: Eta Car is an extremely interesting but as yet poorly-studied source in the millimeter. We have elected to observe all windows in spectral line rather than continuum mode because we expect many additional lines to be detected "serendipitously" in each window. The pioneering observations of Loinard et al (2012) have already revealed the fruitfulness of this approach, showing for example that H13CN 4-3 was detected in the same window as the CO 3-2 line. The lines they observed exhibited complex shapes even with the poor spatial resolution of APEX, so spectral averaging would risk losing essential information and also reducing or removing the archival value of these observations.

RESOLUTION: At 0.2", the Little Homunuculus will start to be resolved, as will the individual Weigelt blobs. This high resolution will allow the first direct comparison to Hubble images on a comparable angular scale.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 9 CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High frequency continuum and CN observations of Eta Car.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Eta Carinae does not fit into a single primary beam at 0.4mm, so 3 individual pointings are required. In order to measure the molecular gas at scales of 4.5 arcseconds, ACA data will be required.
SENSITIVITY: Loinard et al (2012) detected CO 6-5 at a peak brightness temperature of 1K in a 9" beam. Using the same filling factor as in the previous calculations, the peak brightness in the line may be as low as 1 K. Spectral smoothing may be required to get firm detections if the CO-emitting regions are diffuse, but that is not expected.
The continuum sensitivity in a beam is about 4x10^22 cm^-2 following the same assumptions as Band 3. We note that the highest frequency observations in Band 9 are very important for discerning differences in the SED between free-free continuum and dust continuum.

The general justification is the same as other bands, but for direct comparison we have downsampled all windows by a factor of 2.
The spectral structure of Eta Carinae's ejecta is unexplored at high spatial resolution. The clumps may be hot and thermally or turbulently broadened to 10-100 km/s, or they may be cold and narrow. Probably, both cases will be observed. We require the highest spectral resolution for these bands in order to determine the structure in the lines. However, the wide bandwidth is even more important: Eta Car's eject span thousands of km/s in both red and blue, so we need the full bandwidth.

[same as Band 3 CO] DATA RATES: Eta Car is an extremely interesting but as yet poorly-studied source in the millimeter. We have elected to observe all windows in spectral line rather than continuum mode because we expect many additional lines to be detected "serendipitously" in each window. The pioneering observations of Loinard et al (2012) have already revealed the fruitfulness of this approach, showing for example that H13CN 4-3 was detected in the same window as the CO 3-2 line. The lines they observed exhibited complex shapes even with the poor spatial resolution of APEX, so spectral averaging would risk losing essential information and also reducing or removing the archival value of these observations.

RESOLUTION: At 0.2", the Little Homunuculus will start to be resolved, as will the individual Weigelt blobs. This high resolution will allow the first direct comparison to Hubble images on a comparable angular scale. Although the nebula itself extends across 16 arcsec, HST images (reflected light from dust) show that all the dust resides in very compact (0.1-1 arcsec) clumpy structures.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Eta Carinae is the most important of the unstable luminous blue variables (LBVs), and its 19th century Great Eruption is the prototype for eruptive mass ejections that dominate the evolution of very massive stars. Eta Car is unique as the only LBV that has both a detailed photometric record of its eruption and a spatially resolved nebula created by that event for which we can measure the mass directly. Moreover, light echoes from Eta Car's eruption now allow us to reconstruct a spectroscopic time series of the eruption, showing absorption from newly formed molecules. The dust and molecules that formed have now cooled, and the products can be observed directly with ALMA. Previous single-dish submm observations find a nebular mass of 40 solar masses, but the angular resolution of ALMA is required to determine how much of this mass resides in the nebula ejected in the 19th century. Our primary goal in this proposal is to spatially resolve the dust and free-free emission in multiple bands and to definitively measure the total dust mass. The molecular lines will map the 3D kinematics of the nebula and constrain the basic physical conditions and chemistry in the molecular shell.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Astronomy , Arizona, University of
